name: Corn stover, production, average, US, 2022
description:
Corn stover based on  US average corn yeilds and practices extrapolated from historic data to 2022. Includes all crop production processes from field preperation to harvest. Infrastructure, maintenance, and construction of faciilities and equipment is included. Loading/unloading,transport, and storage of material is not included. Grain and components are assumed to be at field-dry conditions of 15.5% moisture. 

The stover process has been seperated from corn to allow for incremental allocation. Only processes directly attributed to stover collection are counted. These processes include additional harvesting energy for single pass harvest, additional nutrients, and hay substitition for loss of potential over-winter cattle feed.

Process has been reviewed by Dr. Dwayne Westfall, Dept Soil and Crop Sciences, Colorado State University. Date of review Sept 10 - 30 2008.                                                                                                             Data from NASS where available. Extrapolation of existing data to 2022 estimates.  Mass based between stover and grain.
category: 11: Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting/1111: Oilseed and Grain Farming

processDocumentation.restrictionsDescription: All information can be accessed by everybody.

exchanges.description: Hay is used to replace over-winter feed lost by harvesting stover
This accounts for fertilizer replacement of nutrients removed in stover.

exchanges.description:
LHV for corn stover, data from Phyllis database http://www.ecn.nl/phyllis/ 
Verified 10/14/08
NO3-N leaching, assuming 30% of fertilizer N applied leaches below the root zone. IPCC 2006: Chapter 11: N2O Emissions from Managed Soils, and CO2 Emissions from Lime and Urea Application. Table 11.3
1 hectare of single pass harvest, scaled to 1.46 hectares because of the increase in material from stover harvest. The .46 is attributed to stover.
